message.content:
Verb tenses are forms of a verb that indicate when an action takes place, typically in relation to the present, past, or future. There are four main tenses in English:

1. Present tense: This tense is used to describe actions happening in the present time.
   - Simple present (I work / She writes)
   - Present continuous (I am working / She is writing)
   - Present perfect (I have worked / She has written)
   - Present perfect continuous (I have been working / She has been writing)

2. Past tense: This tense is used to describe actions that took place in the past.
   - Simple past (I worked / She wrote)
   - Past continuous (I was working / She was writing)
   - Past perfect (I had worked / She had written)
   - Past perfect continuous (I had been working / She had been writing)

3. Future tense: This tense is used to describe actions that will take place in the future.
   - Simple future (I will work / She will write)
   - Future continuous (I will be working / She will be writing)
   - Future perfect (I will have worked / She will have written)
   - Future perfect continuous (I will have been working / She will have been writing)

Each of these tenses can also be formed as progressive or perfect, depending on the context and intended emphasis.
